title: DataViz Makeover 1
description: This data visualisation presents the growth of Singapore's Labour Force Participation Rate (LFPR) from 2009 to 2019.
contents:
1.0 Overview
Data visualisation is published on Tableau Public.
1.1 Clarity vs aesthetics
In terms of aesthetics, the chart provided in the DataViz Makeover 1 assignment looks acceptable. Font styles and colour schemes are easy on the eyes.
However, the presentation of the data itself is not clear. Based on this, the chart falls into Quadrant IV of the matrix:
Clarity vs Aesthetics matrix Source of matrix: https://dataremixed.com/2012/05/data-visualization-clarity-or-aesthetics. Source of graph: https://stats.mom.gov.sg/Pages/Labour-Force-In-Singapore-2019.aspx2.0 Makeover
2.1 Critique of the visualisation, and suggested improvements
2.1.1 Clarity
S/n
Critique
Suggestions for improvement
1
Unclear subtitle. It is not clear what the subtitle “Per Cent” refers to. It almost looks to be put there as an afterthought.
Remove the subtitle and label the appropriate axis with “%”. This will eliminate uncessary text, yet present the percentage values in a more intuitive manner.
2
The x-axis is not explained. There are no labels to explain what the three types of values on the x-axis mean.
Pivot the data such that the percentages are on the x-axis and the age group is on the y-axis, and label the axes accordingly. This will improve the clarity of the visualisation.
3
Age Group is not presented clearly. It would be clearer if percentage was presented on the y-axis instead of the x-axis, as the x axis is typically for presenting time period. Together with the blue and grey lines of the line graph, it looked as though a timeline was being presented. Only upon further examination was it understood to be for presenting age proportion in percentage.
Pivot the data such that age group is presented on the y-axis. This will improve the intuition of the visualisation.
4
Duplicate presentation of information. The two lines of the line graph essentially present the same information as the percentage values in the a-axis. The line graph presented the trend visually, while the x-axis provided the actual percentage values. This duplication would not be needed with better visualization design.
Remove the June 2009 and June 2019 percentage values on the x-axis. This will no longer be necessary once the data is presented appropriately.
2.1.2 Aesthetics
S/n
Critique
Suggestions for improvement
1
Good use of colour to differentiate the two time periods. A more contrasting colour scheme might be better.
Use more appealing colours to enhance the contrast and clarity of the two sets of data being compared.
2
Clear labeling of what the two lines in the line graph represent, and the median ages. However, better designed aesthetics could allow for more concise labeling (using less words).
Include labels as necessary.
3
With thee different values, the x-axis is too cluttered.
This will be solved once the data is pivoted appropriately, as mentioned above.
4
A minor point: although best practice states that number ranges should start from 0, there is no need for the age group to start from 0 in this case, as this graph is meant to present the labour force which is consists of only persons aged 15 years and over (https://stats.mom.gov.sg/SL/Pages/Labour-Force-Introduction.aspx). The age groups presented covers the entire range of legal working age ranges.
No action necessary.
2.2 Sketch of the alternative visualisation
The sketch below is the proposed improved visualisation to address the critique presented above.
Proposed visualisation2.3 Building the visualisation
This visualisation was built using Tableau Desktop Professional Edition 2020.4.0.
S/n
Step
Action
1
Import data into Tableau
Import Excel file into Tableau.
2
Clean the data
The data is not standardised and clean because the formatting of the spreadsheet is not friendly for data importation.
3
Clean the data
Click on the “Cleaned with Data Interpreter” to provide an initial clean-up of the data and allow for easier manual cleaning.
4
Clean the data
Hide the left-most column as it is not useful for this analysis.
5
Clean the data
Rename the “Age (Years) 1” column to “Age Group” for clarity.
6
Clean the data
Check that the “Age” column is of the correct data type (String).
7
Clean the data
Check that the rest of the year columns are of the correct data type (Number[decimal]).
8
Build the visualisation
Drag “2009” and “2019” to the Columns pane.
9
Build the visualisation
Drag “Age Group” to the Rows pane.
10
Build the visualisation
Exclude the “NULL” and “Total” columns from the chart as these are not useful for the analysis.
11
Build the visualisation
Exclude the overlapping age groups, as these will confuse the data presented in the visualisation.
12
Build the visualisation
Sort “Age Group” in descending order.
13
Build the visualisation
Select “Dual Axis” to combine the two charts into one.
14
Build the visualisation
Select “Synchronise Axis” to ensure both charts’ axes match.
15
Build the visualisation
Remove “Show Header” to show only one y-axis.
16
Build the visualisation
Change the 2019 Mark to Bar chart.
17
Build the visualisation
Swap “SUM(2019)” to the front of the Columns pane to display the 2019 chart behind the 2009 chart.
18
Build the visualisation
Edit the range of the x-axis to show the whole range of 0% to 100%. Rename label as “LFPR (%)”.
19
Build the visualisation
Change the view to “Entire View” for visual clarity.
20
Build the visualisation
Edit the chart title.
21
Build the visualisation
Edit the Legend title to “Year”.
22
Build the visualisation
Rename the Sheet.
23
Build the visualisation
The completed chart looks like this:
2.4 Some key observations from the visualisation
S/n
Observation
1
The 25 to 29 age group had the highest LFPR in 2009. Ten years later in 2019, the age group with the highest LFPR was 30 to 34.
2
The largest increase in LFPR from 2009 to 2019 is amongst the 50 to 64, and 65 to 69 age groups. This is expected of a an ageing population.
3
Of all the LFPR age groups, only the 20 to 24 age group declined in LFPR from 2009 to 2019. This is the only exception amongst all the LFPR age groups.
4
4. The lower the age group, the lower the increase in LFPR from 2009 to 2019, with the exception of the 15 to 19 age group, which seemed to reverse the trend compared to the next older age group. This seems to contradict Singapore’s Total Fertility Rate (TFR) which has been declining consistently, but may have been bolstered by the slight up-tick in TFR in 2000.
Thank you for visiting my blog!
 Distill is a publication format for scientific and technical writing, native to the web. Learn more about using Distill at https://rstudio.github.io/distill.

description:

reading what we have to say!
